question: The year was 1891. London was the capital of the world -- the height of modernity, with the hiss of steam and smell of coal in the air. It was also the great cesspool into which all the sinners and criminals of the empire drained. I had come to London, ten years prior, to find a life after the Afghan war. I had hoped to start a medical practice and settle into a nice, steady existence. The life I found was anything but nice and steady. And that had everything to do with one man. My friend, my partner, my burden... ... Sherlock Holmes.
answer: My apologies. Send the bill to John Watson, 221B Baker Street. Head cocked to the left, partial deafness in right ear. First point of attack. Then throat, paralyze vocal chords, stop screaming. Stink of alcohol, heavy drinker -- knuckles to liver. Hhhmm, good cigar. Who do you work for? Watson. Perfect timing.

question: Nice hat.
answer: Just got it. Where's Lestrade?

question: Getting his troops in formation. Is that your blood or theirs?
answer: I don't know. It's an old shirt.

question: You left this behind.
answer: Knew I'd forgotten something. Thought I'd left the stove on.

question: You did.
answer: Right. Shall we?

question: We've gone for the doctor... And one for the rope.
answer: You should've waited for my help.

question: If I had, you'd be cleaning up a corpse and chasing a rumor. Besides, the girl's parents hired me, not the Yard. I can't imagine why they thought you'd need any assistance.
answer: What do you make of that?

question: Some kind of ceremony. Five girls killed beneath cathedrals at the height of the full moon. The double circle's for his own protection.
answer: London will breathe a sigh of relief --

question: 71 over 104... very good, Captain. No -- ground floor. And there'll be a woman's touch, too. I think we can start to wean you off the medicine -- Let's give it a little longer, just to be safe. I'll be right back.
answer: I won't go in there by myself, not while he's in this state.

question: You're not going in at all.
answer: What will I do when you leave? He'll burn the house down around me. What will he do? Couldn't you have a longer engagement?

question: He just needs a new case, that's all. I smell burning. Why don't you take Captain Philips and give him a nice cup of tea.
answer: Come on, Captain, let's go down. It'll be quieter.

question: And perhaps some tea and bread up here when you can. May I join you in the armory?
answer: Please... Watson, I've been working on a device which will suppress the sound of a gunshot. Please... Don't, don't, don't...

question: It needs work. May I see?...
answer: Gently, gently, Watson...

question: It's been three months since the last case. About time you found another one.
answer: I can't but agree. My mind rebels at stagnation. Give me problems, give me work. The sooner the better.

question: Paper? Let's see, we have a letter here from Mrs. Ramsey in Queen's Park -- her husband has gone missing.
answer: He's in Belgium with the scullery maid. Is it December?

question: Yes, Holmes. Lady Radford reports a missing emerald bracelet.
answer: Insurance swindle. Lord Radford likes fast women and slow ponies. I see you're the attending physician at Blackwood's hanging.

question: Yes, it's our last case together and I wanted to see it through to the end. Mr. Lewis is seeking...
answer: There is only one case that intrigues me at present... the curious case of Mrs. Hudson, the absentee landlady. I have been studying her comings and goings and they appear most sinister.

question: There is only one case that intrigues me at present... the curious case of Mrs. Hudson, the absentee landlady. I have been studying her comings and goings and they appear most sinister.
answer: Tea, Mr. Holmes.

question: Is it poisoned, nanny?
answer: There's enough of that in you already.

question: Don't touch that. Everything is in its proper place, as per usual.
answer: He's killed the dog... again.

question: What have you done to Gladstone this time?
answer: I was simply testing a new anesthetic. He doesn't mind.

question: Holmes! As your doctor...
answer: He'll be right as a trivet in no time.

question: ... and your friend, you've been in this room for two weeks. I insist you get out of here.
answer: There's nothing of interest to me out there, on earth, at all.

question: So, you have nothing to do?
answer: Nothing.

question: Then you're free this evening.
answer: Absolutely.

question: For dinner.
answer: Wonderful.

question: The Royale.
answer: My favorite.

question: Mary's coming.
answer: Not available.

question: You're meeting her, Holmes.
answer: Have you proposed yet?

question: I'm still looking for the right ring.
answer: Then it's not official.

question: It's happening, like it or not. Half past eight. The Royale. And wear a jacket. Holmes! You're early.
answer: Fashionably.

question: May I present Miss Mary Morstan.
answer: My pleasure. For the life of me I don't know why it's taken him so long to get us properly introduced.

question: You know this is for eye surgery?
answer: I find that it lifts my spirits.

question: It's a pathological amorbic process, it increases tissue change and weakness. And you know what a black reaction comes on you afterwards.
answer: Look at this. If you play a chromatic scale, they move clockwise. As soon as you switch to a pentatonic scale --

question: Really? What about when you -- oops -- Let's go. Lestrade wants you at Pentonville Prison.
answer: That's your job, not mine.

question: You're Blackwood's last request. Says he has information he'll give only to you.
answer: Look at that structure. What has it been? Five years' work already? Are you aware that is the first combination of bascule and suspension bridge. Very innovative. Oh, I have your cut from last night, by the way. You weren't there so I laid your customary bet -- You're right... I'll keep it with your check book, locked safely away in my drawer. The opera house is featuring Don Giovanni and I could easily procure two tickets if you had some cultural inclination this evening. You have the grand gift of silence, Watson. It makes you quite invaluable as a companion.

question: And your grand gift is the uncanny ability to demoralize people. I was aware she'd been engaged. She told me. Holmes rubs his jaw.
answer: So that's a `no' to the opera then?

question: That's my waistcoat.
answer: It's too small for you.

question: Well, it's my property and I want it back. You go ahead. I've no business with him while he's alive.
answer: Where are all the other prisoners? I'm sure I can find my own way from here, if you have other duties to attend to.

question: Where are all the other prisoners? I'm sure I can find my own way from here, if you have other duties to attend to.
answer: QUOTE from Revelations tbd...

question: Love what you've done with the place.
answer: Thank you for joining me.

question: A small point of concern.
answer: How can I help?

question: I'd already followed the murders with some interest and while my heart went out to the families of the victims, I couldn't but notice a criminal mastery in the stroke of your brush --
answer: You're too kind.

question: However, by comparison, your work in the crypt was akin to a finger painting.
answer: So now you're curious as to whether there's a larger game afoot, and that's why you're really here.

question: Actually, my friend will pronounce you dead shortly and I thought I might keep him company.
answer: Allow me to enlighten you. Your mistake is to imagine that anything earthly has led to this moment. Your error in judgement is to assume I've been holding the brush at all -- I am merely the channel.

question: My only wish is that I'd caught you earlier. I might have spared five lives.
answer: Those lives were a necessity, a sacrifice. Five otherwise meaningless creatures called to serve a greater purpose.

question: I wonder if they'd let Watson and I dissect your brain -- after you're hanged, of course. I'd wager there's some deformity that would be scientifically significant. Then you would serve a greater purpose, too.
answer: Mr. Holmes, you must widen your gaze. I'm concerned you underestimate the gravity of coming events. For you and I are bound on a journey that will twist the very fabric of nature. I sense fragility beneath your mask of logic, and it worries me. Steel your mind, Holmes, I need you.

question: I must say, you've come a long way down from the House of Lords.
answer: But I will rise again.

question: Bon voyage, Blackwood.
answer: Pay attention! Three more shall die, and there is nothing you can do to save them. You must accept that this is beyond your control, or by the time you realize it was you that made it all possible it will be the last sane thought in your head.

question: London's so bleak this time of year. Not that I'm pining for New Jersey. I prefer to travel in the winter. I brought a few souvenirs. Dates from Jordan, tea from Ceylon and olives from Cyclades. I thought we'd have a little tea party to cheer us up. I came across this as I was setting up. Theft of Velasquez portrait from the King of Spain... Missing naval documents lead to resignation of Bulgarian Prime Minister... Scandalous affair ends engagement of Hapsburg Prince to Romanov Princess.
answer: Simply studying your methodology for when the authorities ask me to hunt you down.

question: I don't see my name anywhere.
answer: But your signature is clear. Ah, the Maharajah's missing diamond. Another souvenir?

question: He has a palace full of them. Let's not dwell on the past. By the looks of things you're between cases at the moment.
answer: And you, husbands. No ring?

question: He snored. I'm Irene Adler again and I need your help to find someone. There's nobody more brilliant or who knows London better than you. Plus, it's a wonderful opportunity to see you again. Why are you so suspicious?
answer: Should I answer chronologically or alphabetically?

question: This is all the information you need.
answer: Who are you working for?

question: I'm my own man.
answer: Keep your money. I didn't say I'd take the case.

question: Look at you, I can't believe you ran after her like a schoolboy again. Leaping about, all aflutter. Are you a masochist?
answer: Allow me to explain.

question: Don't you remember what she did to you? She turned you inside out, she made a proper idiot of you. I'm sorry, you were going to explain something...
answer: Thank you, I --

question: I know, instead of just being tricked into being a witness at her wedding like last time --
answer: I don't believe --

question: You dress up as clergyman and actually perform the ceremony. She'd love that.
answer: You've had your fun.

question: What's she after, anyway?
answer: Now it's time to press on. Now it's time to press on.

question: Go on. I won't interrupt.
answer: It doesn't matter --

question: What could she possibly need? An alibi, a beard, a human canoe. She can sit on your back and paddle you up the Thames...
answer: Regrettably, we've had our last case together. Those are my dates.

question: I've already read it. Luke Reordon, four foot ten, red hair, missing two front teeth. Case solved! You're just not her type, Holmes. She likes ginger dwarfs.
answer: Midget!

question: So you agree?
answer: No, I don't agree. It's more than a technicality. You're misrepresenting the dimensions of foreshortened people.

question: I've upset you, I can tell. I've said too much.
answer: No, I'm just saying, one has disproportionate limbs the other does not.

question: Alright. What were you just doing?
answer: Will you allow me to explain.

question: Now, that's the Irene I know. This man intrigues me, Watson. He's got Adler on edge.
answer: Which is no mean feat.

question: She's intimidated, scared...
answer: And yet she works for him. That's bad money. It's nothing to do with me, but leave this case.

question: Well, I may not have a choice. A man has to make a living. After all, I'll be paying the rent entirely on my own.
answer: You know what, I've had just about enough --

question: Us means you.
answer: It's Lord Blackwood, sir. It appears he's come back from the dead.

question: Well that's clever seeing as how I pronounced him dead myself.
answer: A groundsman saw him walking through the graves, just this morning.

question: I'll leave this one in your capable hands. I have tea with Mary and her parents this evening.
answer: It is not my reputation at stake here.

question: Are you taking this seriously?
answer: Like it or not, it's a matter of professional integrity. No girl wants to marry a doctor who can't tell if a man's dead or not. Watson, you'd do well to hide your medical certificates in case they're revoked.

question: Look at this mess. Nothing but standard-issue police bootprints. Any possible evidence there might have been has been trampled.
answer: Scotland Yard at their finest, once again.

question: Now that we have a firm grasp of the obvious...
answer: Lividity is late stage. Diptera deposits are approximately -- -- three quarters of an inch, putting the time of death at ten to twelve hours ago.

question: Inspector, may I see your pen?
answer: Missing two incisors in the upper jaw... Adler's midget.

question: All yours, Inspector. Scratches around the keyhole where the watch is wound. Most drunks are the same, and pawnbrokers scratch the ticket number and their initials inside the lid. This one has five, so the owner -- Now the game is afoot, Watson.
answer: I fail to see how these fish and chips are different from the three other places we passed along the way.

question: Trust me.
answer: Just eat. You know, I've seen things in war that I couldn't explain. I once heard a man predict his death, down to the number and placement of the bullet holes that killed him. You have to admit that a supernatural explanation is at least theoretically possible.

question: Never theorize before you have data. Invariably, you end up twisting facts to suit theories, instead of theories to suit facts. Adler's midget is the key to this. Hmm... scratches around the keyhole, what does that tell you?
answer: The owner was most likely a drunk. Each time he wound the watch his hand would slip, hence the scratches.

question: Very good, Watson! You've developed considerable powers of your own. Let's see now, there are several sets of initials scored into the lid.
answer: Pawnbroker's marks.

question: Excellent. The most recent is M.H...
answer: Maddison and Haig.

question: Oh my Lord, here we are. They should give us an address.
answer: There's one thing you've missed. On the watch.

question: I think not.
answer: The time. Which leads me to deduce that I'm already late for my appointment with Mary. You remember, the one I was leaving for before you talked me into coming to dig up dead bodies with you.

question: No, thank you.
answer: You need to hear what I have to tell you. I see two men, brothers. Not in blood but in bond. I see the letters S and an L, no... wait, a I see madness. A man driven out of his mind by a malign force. I see a letter... the letter M... another M... Mary? You will be married... I see... I see... Patterned table clothes, china figurines, lace doilies...

question: You think you are clever don't you?
answer: She turns to fat...

question: Enough.
answer: Do you have any changes?

question: This is a new low -- even for you.
answer: It's the most honest prediction old Flora has made in years. And you know it yourself, Watson. That is precisely the reason you can't find a suitable ring. You're terrified of a life without the thrill of the macabre, as well you should be.

question: Do you still have my cut from the fight?
answer: Why, do you --

question: Not bad, eh?
answer: Reordon's lodgings should be right around this bend. Here we are... Looks promising. And possibly dangerous. Oh, well, give my regards to Mary.

question: I can spare ten minutes.
answer: He clearly felt something was coming to get him.

question: Something did.
answer: Watson, come take a look at this --

question: Bloody hell...
answer: Ammonium sulfate. Phosphorous... Formaldehyde... Hemlock...

question: Appears he was attempting to follow occult formula with scientific practice. Has he any hydrochloric acid?
answer: Irene was here.

question: Why would she hire you to find him, if she planned to do the job herself?
answer: Maybe it's not the man she's after, but something else. Something he was working on?

question: Ferrocyanide. Sucks the iron right out of the ink. Long as it's not too burnt... He worked for Blackwood.
answer: There's one odor I can't put my finger on. Sweet, almost like perfume... or sugar.... Barley sugar. Hello, gentlemen. Let me guess -- you're here to extinguish any connection between the man who lived here and the man you work for? Curious you'd still be running errands for a dead man. You take them, I'll handle Mr. Sweet tooth.

question: Seems about fair. Holmes! I haven't slept all night. I deserve this... I clearly deserve it. How could I ever be so deluded as to believe I could meet Mary's parents for tea once I let myself be talked into going with you. Now of course I'm in jail.
answer: You're not implying that I am responsible for our current situation are you, Watson? We were set upon, man, it was self- defense.

question: I've used the time to review my notes on our exploits of the last seven months... and I've come to the conclusion that I must be suffering from to some profound psychological aberration. Why else would I continually allow myself to be led into situations where you're deliberately withholding your intentions from me?
answer: You've never complained about my methods before.

question: I'm not complaining... I never complain... I never complain about your violin playing at three in the morning, your mess, your lack of hygiene, your stealing my clothes, your setting our home on fire!
answer: That was an accident... The first time WAS an accident... Ah, Mr. Brownlee. The fifteenth most dangerous man in London.

question: Who could forget that face? I told you, a little nitrate of silver and the warts will be gone in two weeks. Now, if you'll excuse us! Nor am I complaining about the fact that you terrorize my patients and perform outlandish experiments on my dog.
answer: Gladstone's my dog as well. It's in the interest of science.

question: What I do take issue with is your ruthless campaign to sabotage my relationship with Mary.
answer: Watson, I completely understand now. You're overtired and feeling a bit sensitive. What you need is a rest. You and I could go out to the countryside. My brother Mycroft has a small estate near Chichester. It has marvelous grounds and a beautiful folly. We could throw a lamb on the spit.

question: If I were going to the country, I would be going with my future wife --
answer: Certainly. We should have her along. Let's get Gladstone out of the house as well.

question: No, Holmes. Not you. Me and her. You're not --
answer: Invited? Now you're not making any sense, Watson. Why would I not be invited to my own brother's country home?

question: You're not human. You don't get it, do you? You are this... ... without this.
answer: Lestrade -- your usual impeccable timing.

question: Lestrade -- your usual impeccable timing.
answer: You know, in another life, you'd have made an excellent criminal.

question: And you, sir, an excellent policeman.
answer: Tell me you have answers.

question: All in good time.
answer: We don't have time. I've an office full of policemen hanging crosses over their desks. A public that's working itself into a frenzy... Holmes sees a dark, strange carriage waiting, door open.

question: Who's this?
answer: Try to behave yourself. They just paid a small fortune to bail you out.

question: If the rest of his family's dead, why are you still alive?
answer: If you're going to watch me take my clothes off, Sherlock, the least you can do is help me with the buttons. To watch a lady undress without her permission is a criminal offense, Sherlock, and could get you into a lot of trouble... So why don't you come over here and help me instead. That's better.

question: You can stop looking for Reardon.
answer: I knew I could count on you.

question: He was buried in Blackwood's tomb.
answer: Wonderful. Case closed then. Your services are no longer required.

question: I can't help wondering if your employer will be as content with these results? You were uncharacteristically ill at ease in his presence. Your hand was trembling, your gaze was averted. I couldn't see his face, but I spotted chalk on his lapel. A professor perhaps?
answer: The eye patch was a nice touch.

question: But I've never known a professor to carry a gun, and on such a clever contraption.
answer: Let's not argue.

question: We're not. Tell me who you're working for and what he's after.
answer: That's nobody's business but my own.

question: I disagree.
answer: You see, we are arguing.

question: When a man you ask me to find ends up dead in the coffin of the most notorious murderer since Jack the Ripper and that murderer manages to return from the dead, not only is it my business, it's the business of Scotland Yard and the highest levels of the British government. They will certainly consider your reticence to be an obstruction of justice. Which in relation to a crime of this magnitude would certainly mean prison time.
answer: This wine is excellent. You should really try some.

question: So what's it to be?
answer: Do we really have to decide now?

question: You're in over your head this time, Irene.
answer: That's better. Much better. This is the only way it could ever work between us, Sherlock -- one in shackles, the other with the key. I've NEVER been in over my head.

question: How can you live like this -- always a fugitive.
answer: But free. And on my own terms. Just like you -- well, not you at this exact moment -- -- but generally speaking. If anyone asks, please let them know that Mr. O'Neil didn't have time to check out. I hope you don't mind settling the bill. What were you doing consorting with a married business traveller in his hotel room is something you'll have to explain for yourself. Where's Watson when you need him?

question: Why did you drain the water? Crime is common, logic is rare. The decent thing to do is catch the killer, not provide comfort to the corpse. Hmm... What is that? Superb. I suspect this comes from a larger cannister. It'll either be in the pantry, high up where it's warm and dry, or in a linen closet with a vent. And, Constable, you could check the ground under the rear windows for any footprints not your own. Data, data, data! I cannot make bricks without clay! I have no idea what to make of that. Excellent work. Don't forget the wallpaper.
answer: There isn't any.

question: Figure of speech. Since this room is no longer in use, do you mind if I employ it?
answer: Be my guest.

question: Bring him in, boys.
answer: Who was he?

question: My new roommate. He's an inspiring conversationalist.
answer: Really.

question: No, he's your friend from Reordon's. He didn't survive Dredger landing on him. Poor fellow. But there is some consolation in the knowledge that he can still be of service to his fellow men. Elbows and arms stained with blood, but older than his own injuries. Plenty of it, layer on layer... Though none of it human. A butcher perhaps...? What else? Hm -- predominantly yellow flame, but with distinct green bursts. Sulfurous. He spent lots of time around industrial work and very little around a wash basin. Coal... river silt... That plus the river silt and industrial slag on his trousers puts him squarely in...
answer: Nine Elms.

question: Well done. Now, you didn't happen to pack the Lord's Register of members' interests, did you? See what Blackwood admits to owning.
answer: It's endless, he's had a hand in just about everything that's not good for you.

question: Something brutal by the river...
answer: Woolwich Arsenal... Limehouse Chemical... Queenshithe Slaughterhouse, Nine Elms!

question: That's it, Watson! This should lead us right to Blackwood.
answer: Not us, you.

question: Right. Well uh... best of luck with everything, then.
answer: Same to you. Not again. Yes, I know. Don't give me that look, Gladstone.

question: Are you mad, Coward? Have you any idea what he's capable of?
answer: Of course he does. It's why he's here. I am humbled. I am honored. My powers and my assets -- munitions, shipping, industry -- they were given to me for a purpose. A magnificent and simple purpose. A different future... a future ruled by us. You've made policy in secret for centuries. Now, you'll make it openly. The first act is a necessary one, for without death there can be no rebirth... ... at noon tomorrow, we will take the first step towards a new chapter in history. England will know our power. Then, the whole world will. Across the Atlantic lies a colony that was once ours, and will be again. Their civil war weakened them; their government is as corrupt and ineffective as ours. We'll take it from them. With their resources and our power, we'll remake the world, we'll create the future. Are you with me?

question: No, sir, we are not! The powers he's playing with are beyond any man's control.
answer: They're limitless -- even death holds no sway.

question: Help me stop him before it's too late.
answer: I wouldn't do that. Come, drink your allegiance here. You control the police. Use them.

question: What are you doing with my gun?
answer: Oh, please.

question: It was an honest mistake --
answer: There was nothing honest about it. Come on, let's get this over with.

question: The one on the left seems more attentive, might prove easily distracted. The big one's been drinking -- whether for courage or from habit... Watson? They cleared something out of here, not minutes ago...
answer: Holmes. You need to see this. One-eighteen. It's a date, a time?

question: It's your turn in shackles this time.
answer: But this time no key, unfortunately.

question: I've been meaning to ask you something --
answer: Well, I'm a captive audience. You had a question.

question: Ah. Yes. Do you still maintain you're not in over your head?
answer: In some countries steam is considered excellent therapy for the skin. I have to say -- it's overrated. Sherlock? Thank you so much. I owe you.

question: You owe me information. No more games, Irene.
answer: Blackwood's manufactured large- scale weapons for years. Lately there've been rumors of something new. More powerful than anything else. And... magical. My job is to find out if the rumors are true. I would say they are.

question: WAATTTSSSSSONNN!!!!
answer: There's an order for your arrest all the way from the top, sir -- so you'll have to hit me now.

question: From Lord Coward?
answer: Yes, sir, so make it look good.

question: What are you administering?
answer: Morphia. A sixth of a grain, for the pain. There are four pieces of shrapnel. The surgeon should be along shortly.

question: Are they subcutaneous, or deeper?
answer: They're near the carotid artery.

question: Get a mirror, I'll extract them myself.
answer: I can't authorize that, Doctor. We must first manage the pain and combat the infection.

question: I haven't time for that. My friend is in dire --
answer: Your friend? What kind of friend takes a retired soldier, who's served his country and deserves a peaceful, private life, and puts him so directly in harm's --

question: The best and wisest man I've ever known.
answer: But evidently not wise enough to value your life over his misadventures.

question: Excuse me --
answer: I have other... patients.

question: Do you really? Doctor. You have nothing more to say to me?
answer: Um... I'll check in on him again shortly.

question: Writing and sweating on the bed in the attic. Holmes sees a hazy image of Irene. She leans over him smiling sweetly then wraps her hands around his neck and starts to strangle him. Watson...?
answer: Interesting artwork. You look bloody awful.

question: What about the shrapnel in your arm?
answer: Took it out myself. Mary said I had a lousy doctor.

question: She brought you here?
answer: Yes, oddly, it seems she might understand the power of partnership.

question: What time is it?
answer: It's half past nine.

question: Excellent brew, but I believe my head requires something a bit stronger to clear the --
answer: I brought you this...

question: Oh, I poisoned that one.
answer: With your own venom no doubt.

question: Better a snake than a lap dog.
answer: There's a new field in the treatment of abnormal personalities -- it's called psychology. It appears you're what's considered a para-neurotic deviant with anti-social proclivities. Quite severe. And untreatable.

question: Oh, that solves the great mystery as to how you became inspector.
answer: I have five minutes before my next engagement, why don't you regale me with your stories of conspiracies. Thank you, Lestrade, if you could wait outside.

question: I'm curious, Coward, did you assist Blackwood in all the murders or just the one I prevented? Very distinctive those hand-made shoes of yours, but the price of quality is the unique imprint they leave. Nonetheless, I confess to being completely out-matched. I could deduce very little from my investigation. Fortunately, there is nothing more stimulating than a case where everything goes against you. How many members of parliament do you intend to murder at noon today? Man, ox, eagle, lion -- the lion is parliament, isn't it?
answer: Very clever. But it's not murder, Mr. Holmes. It's mercy. We are giving the weak masses a strong shepherd. Don't you see it's for their own good?

question: No, but I don't care much what you think. I simply wanted to know the location of Blackwood's final ceremony, and now you have given it to me.
answer: I have told you nothing.

question: But your clothes say infinitely more than you ever hope. The mud smeared on your boots from where you've been walking... A touch of red stock brick dust on your knee, from where you've been kneeling... A small bandage on your thumb from where you've been vowing... A faint aroma of excrement, from where you have been standing.
answer: It's a shame you made an enemy out of Blackwood, Holmes, you would have made a valuable ally. The powers at our disposal are far greater than you can imagine.

question: You and Blackwood laid the final touches to your ceremony in the sewers beneath parliament less than an hour ago. Both Houses met today. The entire government will be present.
answer: How terrible is wisdom, Holmes, when it brings no profit to the wise. We take power at noon.

question: Will be dead at the strike of noon.
answer: As if by magic. There will be no one left to stop Blackwood and his followers from assuming control. Seven minutes to twelve... I wouldn't.

question: I'll keep these under wraps.
answer: Take this.

question: Why hurry off, give it a try.
answer: You're better off without her, Holmes! I planned to kill a handful of senile old men to make this empire strong... but now because of you thousands are going to die. All I have to do is break this cylinder. The wind will do the rest. And you'll be the first.

question: There was never any magic. Only conjuring tricks. The simplest involved paying people off, like the prison guard... Who pretended to be possessed outside your cell. Your reputation and your jailers' fear did the rest. Others required more elaborate preparation, like the sandstone slab that covered your tomb. You had it broken before your burial then put back together using a mild adhesive. An ancient Egyptian recipe I believe -- a mixture of egg and honey. Designed to be washed away by the rain or eaten by animals. Arranging for your father to drown in his own bathtub required more modern science. Very clever of Reordon to find a paralytic that was activated by the combination of copper and water and was therefore undetectable once the bath water was drained. That might have been quite challenging had he not also tested it on some unfortunate amphibians. The death of Standish was a real mystery, until you used the same compound to blow up the wharf. An odorless, tasteless, flammable liquid -- yet it burned with an unusual pinkish hue. Did Standish mistake it for rain as he entered your Temple? All it took was a spark. A simple rigged bullet in his gun. Ingenious. Like all great performers you saved your piece de resistance for the end. Had it worked, your followers in Parliament would have watched unharmed as their colleagues were dying around them. They didn't know that you had given them the antidote -- at one of your ceremonies I suspect. Instead, they would have believed it was magic and that you harnessed the ultimate power. You hated your father and the other members of the Temple of the Four Orders for what they did to you. How satisfying it must have been to use their own system against them.
answer: Cut me loose, Holmes!

question: You better hope that it's nothing more than superstition as you performed all the rituals perfectly. First, the world will see you for what you are. Then you will hang... properly this time.
answer: We'll see about that shall we. It's a long journey from here to the rope.

question: We'll see about that shall we. Oh, Irene...
answer: It looks like rain.

question: We've still got a moment.
answer: You were right, he is a professor. Moriarty. Key's in the watch pocket. You'll miss me, Sherlock.

question: Sadly, yes.
answer: It'll be a hell of a trick if Blackwood comes back from this one.

question: Thank you, Lestrade.
answer: Now you're going to be even more arrogant and insufferable than ever. You're welcome, detective. Is the woman up there?

question: One moment. Please make sure this one is put on the desk in the front room.
answer: What's in all those notebooks?

question: Nothing really... Just a few scribbles... cases we've worked on over the years.
answer: All your adventures... I'd love to read them sometime.

question: I still can't believe he's given us that ring.
answer: Do you think he's finally come to terms with you leaving?

question: I hate to stop when he's on a roll. Do carry on, Holmes.
answer: The executioner attached it to a harness, thus allowing the weight to be distributed around the waist and the neck to remain intact. My lord, I can't feel my cheeks. Might we continue this at ground level?

question: How did you manage it, Holmes?
answer: I managed it with braces, belts and a coat hook. Please, Watson, my tongue is going next. I'll be of no use to you at all.

question: Mr. Holmes... Inspector Lestrade asks that you come with me, right away.
answer: What is it this time, Clarky?

question: It's one of our sergeants, sir. He went missing in the sewers, the day you stopped Lord Blackwood... Well, a maintenance man found his body this morning. We believe the sergeant was our first man on the scene. Shot in the head.
answer: Were there powder burns on his eyebrows?

question: I'd wager there's a piece missing.
answer: So you're saying Moriarty was after a part of the machine and not the poison.

question: The wire-free invention was the game all along. Imagine being able to control any device simply by sending a command via radio waves.
answer: Adler was just a diversion. Well...

question: I'd wager there's a piece missing.
answer: Wager, Watson... I thought those days were behind you. Excellent deduction, however.

question: Moriarty was after the machine not the poison.
answer: Blackwood's wire-free invention was the game all along. It is undoubtedly the more dangerous and the more valuable of the two... Irene was just a diversion.

question: Well...
answer: I'll walk out with you... An honor working with you, Doctor.
